trans-unit.source: (string|false) Read data on success, false on failure.
(string|false) Referer URL on success, false on failure.
(string|false) Returns read string, otherwise false.
(string|false) Returns the origin URL if headers are sent. Returns false if headers are not sent.
(string|false) Screenshot file. False if the theme does not have a screenshot.
(string|false) Script on success, false otherwise.
(string|false) String on success, false on failure.
(string|false) Table alias if found, otherwise false.
(string|false) Table-prefixed value to used in the ORDER clause. False otherwise.
(string|false) The JSON encoded string, or false if it cannot be encoded.
(string|false) The JSON-encoded translated strings for the given script handle and text domain. False if there are none.
(string|false) The action name or False if no action was selected
(string|false) The actual mime type or false if the type cannot be determined.
(string|false) The canonical URL, or false if the post does not exist or has not been published yet.
(string|false) The current working directory on success, false on failure.
(string|false) The embed HTML on success, otherwise the original URL. ->maybe_make_link() can return false on failure.
(string|false) The file path to where the attached file should be, false otherwise.
(string|false) The format if successful. False otherwise.
(string|false) The found URL.
(string|false) The full path to the main plugin file, or false.
(string|false) The group on success, false on failure.
(string|false) The hashed $data, or false on failure.
(string|false) The location of the remote path, false on failure.
(string|false) The location of the remote path, false to cease looping.
(string|false) The mime type on success, false on failure.
(string|false) The path to the translation file or false if no translation file was found.
(string|false) The permalink URL or false if post does not exist.
(string|false) The post embed URL on success, false if the post doesn't exist.
(string|false) The post type archive permalink.
(string|false) The post type feed permalink.
(string|false) The timestamp.
(string|false) The valid IP address, otherwise false.
(string|false) URI if IRI is valid, false otherwise.
(string|false) URL path to CSS stylesheet for Administration Screens.
(string|false) Unique ID for usage as array key or false if $priority === false and $function is an object reference, and it does not already have a unique id.
(string|false) Username of the owner on success, false on failure.
(string|false) Value to used in the ORDER clause. False otherwise.
(string|false) XML string on success, false on error.

: get_admin_page_parent()
: get_admin_page_title(), or simply global $title
: global $plugin_page.

: Equivalent to calling wp_set_post_terms() for each custom taxonomy in the array. If the current user doesn’t have the capability to work with a taxonomy, then you must use wp_set_object_terms() instead.
: Equivalent to calling wp_set_post_categories().
: Equivalent to calling wp_set_post_tags().

: If post_type is ‘page’, will attempt to set the page template. On failure, the function will return either a WP_Error or 0, and stop before the final actions are called. If the post_type is not ‘page’, the parameter is ignored. You can set the page template for a non-page by calling update_post_meta() with a key of ‘_wp_page_template’.
: If providing a post_status of ‘future’ you must specify the post_date in order for WordPress to know when to publish your post. See also Post Status Transitions.

'get_schedule' filter added.

‘get_$taxonomy’ hook – Takes two parameters the term Object and the taxonomy name. Must return term object. $taxonomy will be the taxonomy name, so for example, if ‘category’, it would be ‘get_category’ as the filter name. Useful for custom taxonomies or plugging into default taxonomies.
‘get_term’ hook – Takes two parameters the term Object and the taxonomy name. Must return term object. Used in get_term() as a catch-all filter for every $term.
Requests::request(): for values returned by this method
WP_Customize_Custom_CSS_Setting constructor.

query_posts() is a way to alter the main query that WordPress uses to display posts. It does this by putting the main query to one side, and replacing it with a new query. To clean up after a call to query_posts, make a call to wp_reset_query(), and the original main query will be restored.

query_posts() is meant for altering the main loop. It does so by replacing the query used to generate the main loop content. Once you use query_posts(), your post-related global variables and template tags will be altered. Conditional tags that are called after you call query_posts() will also be altered – this may or may not be the intended result.
query_posts() is only one way amongst many to query the database and generate a list of posts. Before deciding to use query_posts(), be sure to understand the drawbacks.

get_events_transient_key — Generates a transient key based on user location.
get_request_args — Builds an array of args to use in an HTTP request to the w.org Events API.
get_unsafe_client_ip — Determines the user's actual IP address and attempts to partially anonymize an IP address by converting it to a network ID.
maybe_log_events_response — Logs responses to Events API requests. — deprecated
trim_events — Prepares the event list for presentation.
__construct — Constructor.
enqueue — Enqueue control related scripts/styles.
content_template — Render a JS template for the content of the position control.
render_content — Don't render the control content from PHP, as it's rendered via JS on load.
content_template — Render a JS template for control display.
enqueue — Enqueue control related scripts/styles.
json — Refresh the parameters passed to the JavaScript via JSON.
render_content — Don't render the control content from PHP, as it's rendered via JS on load.
__construct — Constructor.
content_template — Render a JS template for the content of the color picker control.
enqueue — Enqueue scripts/styles for the color picker.
render_content — Don't render the control content from PHP, as it's rendered via JS on load.
to_json — Refresh the parameters passed to the JavaScript via JSON.
__construct — Constructor.
active — Check whether control is active to current Customizer preview.
active_callback — Default callback used when invoking WP_Customize_Control::active().
check_capabilities — Checks if the user can use this control.
content_template — An Underscore (JS) template for this control's content (but not its container).
enqueue — Enqueue control related scripts/styles.
get_content — Get the control's content for insertion into the Customizer pane.
get_link — Get the data link attribute for a setting.
input_attrs — Render the custom attributes for the control's input element.
json — Get the data to export to the client via JSON.
link — Render the data link attribute for the control's input element.
maybe_render — Check capabilities and render the control.
print_template — Render the control's JS template.
render — Renders the control wrapper and calls $this->render_content() for the internals.
render_content — Render the control's content.
